Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
transformed_texts:
My neighborhood in this massive city is a real melting pot.  Residential areas pop up randomly between all these businesses - offices, shops, restaurants, you name it. There's always something new to try, whether it's a fancy restaurant or a quirky little boutique.  Big brands definitely have their place, but these independent shops are gaining popularity, popping up in malls and lining the streets, bringing a touch of excitement to what would otherwise be quiet neighborhoods.  And speaking of excitement, there are a couple of parks nearby that are always bustling with families.  

This diversity extends to the people too. We've got a big LGBTQ+ community, a thriving Orthodox Jewish community, and a bunch of folks who've moved here from the former Soviet Union, all in one small area.  Venture a bit further out, and you'll find even more cultures represented.  It's like a mini United Nations with "Korea Town," "China Town," "Little Armenia," and so many more, all just a short (or long, depending on traffic) drive away.  Speaking of traffic, this city is notorious for it.  Even a 10-mile journey can easily take two hours during rush hour.  Walking isn't really an option, since the city is massive and people are glued to their cars.  Which, ironically, leads to the city being choked with cars and parking being a nightmare. 

Adding to the chaos, they're constantly building new apartment buildings, which is great for newcomers but makes existing residents groan at the thought of even more people and traffic.  But hey, not everyone wants to live in a giant apartment building.  My neighborhood has a mix of houses, from small bungalows to sprawling mansions, and everything in between.  You've got your single-family homes, duplexes, and smaller apartment complexes.  

And the people?  A real mix of ages, but to be honest, I don't know most of them.  It's not as tight-knit as it used to be back when I was a kid and spent my days playing with my next-door neighbor and a few other neighborhood kids.

My neighborhood is a bit of a time capsule, a snapshot of a bygone era. Most of the houses are single-family dwellings, some split into two while still attached, creating a unique kind of clustered intimacy. My place has a small front yard and a tiny driveway – a picture of suburban normalcy that once embodied the American dream.  

There's a bittersweet nostalgia hanging in the air. While the dream feels a bit distant now, the houses still whisper of a time when things were simpler, when the dream felt more attainable. People aren't as optimistic as they used to be, the yards aren't as manicured, but there are still cars in every driveway, and kids playing like the world revolves around their games. The old public school, standing strong after almost 90 years, seems to promise a future to the young while stirring memories in the older folks. 

The churches are mostly empty, but the basketball courts are always buzzing. Every house has its own story, its own character, yet they all share a similar feeling – a sense of quiet community. The highlight is Super "A," the local supermarket run by a Yemeni family, probably the only Arab family around.  

Most folks are African American, and they've been here for generations, their roots intertwined with the neighborhood's history.  The streets are wide, and kids play football, stopping only for cars to pass. There are stories passed down from parent to child, tales of a time when everyone knew everyone. The karate school, once a hub of youthful aspirations, is now a pharmacy – reflecting a shift in priorities. 

Even the old movie theater, showing classic films at bargain prices, still draws crowds, mostly the older residents who appreciate a night out without the distractions of the latest releases. The expressway cuts through the town next door, a constant reminder of the outside world, a world that the town elders, with their yearning for a simpler time, have actively kept at bay. They ultimately blocked the petition for a local exit, fearing it would disrupt the town's tranquility.  A new high school is being built, and the town is debating a mascot. My vote? A cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin – the perfect embodiment of our town's unique blend of old and new.

You might pass it over at first glance. It's tucked behind shops, not exactly a place that screams "desirable living."  Not unless you're into the kind of hidden gems most people overlook.  But if you venture past the old, deserted Whole Foods and the hotels that only see action during family reunions, you'll stumble upon a vibrant community.  Imagine apartment complexes squeezed together like Russian nesting dolls, meticulously disassembled and lined up along the road.  The first ones you encounter are known for some shady dealings, so let's not dwell on those.  Appearances can be deceiving, after all. But the complexes next door, and the ones beyond those, are a world apart, a secret known only to a select few.  Across from them sits a community college branch, a sleepy collection of buildings where students shuffle in with coffee, yawning at 7 a.m. They trudge through the iron gates, which creak open one by one, while commuters bellow in frustration at the morning rush. The road intersects with another residential street, leading to a park on one side and a rehabilitation center on the other. The center's porch is decked out with cheerful furniture, and a lazy ceiling fan stirs the heavy summer air. 

Kids zoom around the park, cartwheeling and giggling, while bees buzz lazily around the flower patches.  Seniors stroll their dogs, shaking their heads at the skateboarders and exchanging knowing glances with the teenage girls huddled by the playground, gossiping about boys and the latest viral videos.   A strip mall nearby houses a sushi joint serving cheap eats, a swimming supply store, and a nail salon – a one-stop shop for pool parties and manicures.  There's also a frozen yogurt place, the DIY kind, where teens often gather, clutching cold cups of sugary goodness while they try out their latest skateboarding tricks and puff on vapes, convinced it makes them cool.   This neighborhood is pure Americana, a snapshot of the sleepy south where time seems to stand still.

"Where's everything?" she asked as we drove past endless cornfields. I knew she'd be shocked by how empty it all seemed. She was from a town where you could walk to the grocery store in five minutes, she'd never seen this much open space before. Overwhelmed by the sea of corn, I told her about growing up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally understood who I was and where I came from.  We turned onto a two-lane country road, passing a quarry filled with water. Just past it was the small development where I live. Most of the houses are made of brick and stucco, each one with at least half an acre of land that everyone takes pride in keeping up. In the spring, flowers bloom everywhere, alongside the midwestern trees that change colors with each season. The driveways are always filled with fancy Mercedes-Benz cars, gleaming in the afternoon sun after a good wash.  

As we continued down the road towards my grey stucco house, my Korean neighbor was out in his yard, as always, with a friendly smile. He spends all day mowing his lawn, singing along to the hum of his mower. Everyone in the neighborhood finds it amusing, but he's a genuinely kind guy with a fascinating past. He's gotten older and his wit isn't what it used to be. Back in the day, he was a doctor, but now he mostly blends in with the grass and his John Deere Zero Turn mower. Finally, we reached my house. 

Geese wander the side yard, chased by our terrier. Out back, a small stream flows into the quarry. You can hear bullfrogs, the gentle gurgling of the stream, and the occasional "moo" from the nearby farms.  Across a handmade wooden bridge is a peaceful haven filled with trees, herbs, and wildflowers. This was where I spent most of my childhood. Whether building tree forts or "hunting" (which mostly involved chasing critters), there was always something to do, and there was always a neighborhood friend around. 

The winters in our small town can be really harsh, but they're also beautiful. The yard transforms from a lush green into a bare wilderness. The trees that once boasted vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers become just skeletons of bark. When it snows, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is covered with snow angels made by my little sister and snowmen.  My sister and I fought constantly as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapons of choice. We'd build massive igloo-like forts to store our "arsenal" of branches.  In our own little winter wonderland, we played pretend, lost in a world where nothing else mattered. We were just carefree kids.

Portland, Oregon, has this thing about "weird,"  a vibe that's more than just a slogan painted on a building that somehow manages to be a pizza place, bar, music venue, and, well, let's just say it pushes the boundaries of legality. It's a place where the phrase "Keep Portland Weird" is like a rallying cry. 

Some see it as a nostalgic nod to the days when Portland was a hidden gem, less fancy and more affordable, where quirky subcultures thrived.  Others see it as an invitation: come to Portland, where being different isn't just accepted, it's celebrated.  

Even with the influx of folks from California and all the new condos popping up, Portland still holds onto its weirdness.  It's not about blindly accepting everything, but it's about embracing the unconventional. We've got our share of modern conveniences and dramas, just like everywhere else. We buy our stuff from China, have yoga studios, and yes, even hipsters. Maybe "weird" just means we take things a little less seriously.

Take my neighborhood, for example. It's full of colorful houses, front yards bursting with flowers, herbs, and veggies, and these magical things called "free boxes" that show up in the summer. These aren't your average cardboard boxes; they're treasure troves, filled with everything from clothes and books to who-knows-what. You never know what you'll find, but it's always a surprise.

That sense of wonder, that magic of discovery, that's what Portland is all about, at least to me. But there are a million ways to be weird in Portland, a million different flavors of "unique." You've got people going to goat yoga (yes, yoga with real goats!), cheering on the Timbers soccer team, or simply embracing the weirdness in their own way.

Portland is a city full of dreamers, people chasing their passions, or at least daydreaming about it over a pint at the local pub.  We've got our problems, sure. Drug addiction is a real issue, stemming from deeper mental health struggles, and the endless rain doesn't exactly help. Homelessness is another challenge, with a complex web of causes and no easy solutions.  The non-homeless population grapples with feelings of compassion and frustration, just like everywhere else.  But even with those struggles, Portland remains true to its heart, a place where being different is not just tolerated, it's celebrated.

The mountains are always there, like silent guardians in the north, watching the sun rise and set every day.  No matter how busy I get, how lost in work or life, they're still there, strong and steady, unfazed by everything else. On days when stress is at its peak, they seem to call out to me, and when I turn to them, they offer a sense of peace and strength to carry on.

I first fell for this place when I started college. The mountains north of campus were what truly captivated me. Sure, the university itself has its own beauty – the buildings, the ponds, the trees – all hold a special place in my heart. But the mountains reign supreme.

The town itself is charming in its own right. There are countless cafés where I spent countless hours fueled by caffeine and study sessions. A short walk or bus ride takes you to the downtown area, where the old, faded brick buildings create an atmosphere of history and vibrancy, almost as bustling as the nearby city.  But it's a short journey back to the quiet small-town feel, just past the library. This blend of urban energy and peaceful suburbs gives the town a unique charm, inviting exploration and making it easy to create lasting memories.

There are good memories, like walking past the rusty swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter, or sprinting through the busy downtown to catch a movie at the fancy theater thanks to a student discount. But there are also tough memories, because every place holds those too. The ponds, in particular, have been both a place of reflection and a spot for late-night existential crises. I've spent many a night there, watching turtles, ducks, and insects go about their lives, contemplating my own purpose in the face of life's mysteries.

One day, I was walking past the pond, the park, and the typical suburban houses, until I reached the main street. The sun was shining brightly on the palm trees, painting the sky in hues of blue and yellow. As I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was heading north. There they were, as they always had been – the majestic mountains, towering over everything else, silently reminding me to keep going.

Alright, so you're thinking of checking out Bensonhurst, Brooklyn? Finding it won't be a problem, trust me. Public transport's pretty much the go-to in NYC, and Bensonhurst's a classic city neighborhood. You'll definitely feel that New York vibe.  

Get ready for a serious dose of Asian shops everywhere you look. The neighborhood's been welcoming a ton of Asian folks over the last couple of decades, so you'll practically stumble into an Asian-owned store every block. Supermarkets and laundromats are like the kings of this neighborhood, and honestly, they're a hit with locals too. The food in the supermarkets is amazing, prices are super reasonable, and let's be real, convenience is key. I'm talking four Asian supermarkets within a two-minute stroll from where I am! Grocery shopping?  A breeze.

Now, don't get me wrong, Bensonhurst isn't just an Asian enclave. It's a melting pot, with immigrants, first-gen and second-gen Americans all hanging out.  Most of the big businesses are Asian-owned, but there's also a recently revamped park nearby with a ton to offer: basketball courts, soccer and baseball fields, handball courts, swings, a playground, even a water fountain for the little ones. You'll see all walks of life mixing it up in the park, just like the rest of NYC.

Corporate giants aren't really Bensonhurst's thing. Mostly, you'll find co-op buildings and condos, but two-family houses are the real MVPs here. The people are generally friendly, though they can be a bit loud.  Think cars blasting music, revving engines that'll wake you up at the crack of dawn.  

If you're visiting at night, stay aware of your surroundings.  Bensonhurst is safe enough, but you know how it is in any big city – people can be unpredictable.  You might encounter some troublemakers, bullies, or even petty thieves. I've had some run-ins with bullies in the past (physical assault, back when I was younger), and recently, there have been some package thefts. 

And one last thing – dog owners, please clean up after your pets!  Despite the fines in NYC, seemingly nobody here follows the rules. You'll be dodging dog waste left and right on your way to the train station or the supermarket. It's my biggest pet peeve!  Watch your step, and keep those shoes clean!

My neighborhood is perched on a steep hill, the highest point everyone calls "workout hill" due to the runners who tackle it daily.  Sidewalks are a rare commodity here, so everyone walks right on the road, a bumpy path pockmarked with divots and patched wires. Rain and storms are frequent visitors, battering the power lines with branches and debris.  The constant repairs leave them looking like a haphazard patchwork.  Towering evergreen trees blanket the landscape, but locals seem to despise them, striving to cut them down for an unobstructed ocean view. This explains the abundance of houses perched high on the hill, boasting large glass-fronted second stories that frame the bay. Sunsets are breathtaking, with the water glowing from below and the sky ablaze with orange hues. However, the frequent overcast days mean most sunlight filters through a hazy veil, leaving most days damp and shrouded in mist.  Everything succumbs to moss: roofs, cars, railings, even my car sat in the driveway for a month and sprouted a thick green fuzz.

Despite a school nearby, kids are scarce. The neighborhood is dominated by retirees, with dogs replacing children. They roam freely, often seen lounging in lawns or chasing each other down the street. Doors and windows better be kept shut, or you might find a furry intruder snooping inside. I once had one waltz into my living room – not the best houseguest! Add to that the mischievous rabbits who dig up gardens and burrow into lawns, a source of amusement for my cats who have hunted most of them out.  We also have our share of birds: sparrows, hummingbirds, occasional hawks or eagles chased off by the neighborhood crows.  

There are no shops around, but a short hike downhill leads to waterfront restaurants serving up fresh seafood. The beach is limited, but the rocks along the shore offer endless fun for tossing into the water. The bay itself is narrow, with the opposite shore visible even through the mist on most days.

Alright, so I live in this typical suburban place in a small town down South.  Picture it: a street connecting two major highways, which means more traffic than I'd prefer, but hey, at least it's not boring. It's a pretty quiet neighborhood though. People kinda stick around, so I know most of the folks here. Everyone's busy with their lawn care and regular stuff, you know, the usual. In the winter, we crank up the sledding down the hill on our street. We're on the corner, so we see everyone coming and going.  We even keep track of the different cars that drive by.  If a strange vehicle rolls through, we definitely notice it.  Some neighbors like to walk for exercise or walk their dogs. Kids are out on their bikes, just your standard neighborhood scene. We work from home, so we're around a lot. It's the four of us: my wife, me, and our two daughters, who are eleven and fourteen.  Guess everyone else is used to seeing us around too.  We get outside and play, even in the rain sometimes.  We fire up the grill on the back deck every once in a while, and the smell of barbecue just fills the air. It seems like someone's always mowing the lawn around here. You can hear that lawnmower droning pretty much every day from spring to fall, when the grass finally chills out. We've got a ton of trees around us, because the area used to be all woods, so there's plenty of shade.  But that means a whole lot of leaves in the fall, which means raking and burning. I actually kind of love the smell of burning leaves, so that's a good sign that fall is here.  We haven't really had much of a winter lately, so it feels like fall just keeps going and going. Our garage is in the back, so we practically never use the front door unless someone knocks, which isn't often. I like to tinker with my truck or other projects in the garage, and when the garage doors are open, it's like I'm more connected to the neighborhood. Holidays are pretty quiet around here. Thanksgiving brings some out-of-town relatives, so there are extra cars everywhere for a bit. It's the same for Mother's Day and Christmas. Overall, I dig it here. If it weren't for the through-street traffic, it would be perfect.

My neighborhood is smack-dab in the middle of the high desert – think dirt, dirt, and more dirt. Unless you've actually lived here, you probably can't grasp the feeling of constantly seeing brown. And when you do see a lawn, you know that person is shelling out a small fortune to keep it that way. Back in the 90s when I first moved here, houses were spread out like stars in the night sky. Now, it's still pretty spread out, but there are tons of new additions popping up everywhere. Honestly, it's getting more and more city-like every day, but I guess that's happening everywhere these days.  

Most of the people here are super friendly, just like in any city, there are good parts and bad parts. I'm surrounded by friendly old folks in my neighborhood, so I guess it's a pretty decent place to live.  

When it comes to shopping, it's mostly chains like Food 4 Less and Smart & Final. If you're looking for anything upscale, you've gotta hit the road. I don't see any Whole Foods or anything like that around here.

Based on what I see, the most common jobs in town are in construction. I think it's because this city is still developing – there's a ton of open space left to build on.  That kinda freaks me out, though. I like things the way they are now. I left a big city, and I'm not itching to go back.

Speaking of construction, that's where my full-time gig is – I'm a drywall and T-bar installer. 

What I love about living here is the wildlife. People come here for all sorts of reasons, but the stark beauty of the desert is a big draw. The climate and landscape have created these challenging ecosystems that need protection. They're home to all sorts of cool creatures. It's important for us humans to learn about our wild neighbors so we can coexist peacefully. My family and I have adjusted really well to the wildlife. My three kids are obsessed with lizards and desert bugs. Right now, they're out there trying to catch some specimens. 

As for tourist attractions, we've got a few. Victorville is a great place for families to experience the desert. It's a different kind of experience, for sure. If you're planning a visit, try to time it with the San Bernardino County Fair. It's a blast. Also, check out Wrightwood nearby – you can see the snow-covered mountains and even take some winter sports lessons.

If you're interested in the natural history and culture of the high desert, the Victor Valley Museum is worth a visit. They've got geological and paleontological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical objects that tell the story of Victorville's development.

Okay, so when people ask about my neighborhood, it's a bit different than theirs, I reckon. Most folks probably picture a bunch of houses and families, right? Well, my "hood" is the college campus I live on. My dorm mates are my crew, and the whole campus is my stomping ground.  

Sure, it's not your typical neighborhood, but it's got the usual stuff: places to live, people, shops, and even a park. Let's break it down. 

First, the digs. We've got apartments, regular houses rented out to alumni, and, of course, the dorms where most of us undergrads hang. Apartments usually have a few folks per room, maybe 20 or so in a building. Houses are rarer, mostly for alumni, and then there's the dorms, packed with hundreds of students, two to a room. 

Then there's the people. My school's all about diversity, so my neighborhood's a melting pot. You've got folks from all walks of life, all ages, all backgrounds.  The staff lives in the houses, newer students are in the dorms, and the older ones usually snag apartments. 

There's too much to say about the people, so let's skip to the good stuff: the shops and the park! My campus is pretty self-contained, so we've got our own food joints, clothes stores, even a grocery store.  And the park? It's everyone's hangout, always clean and safe, thanks to all of us looking out for each other.

Okay, so I've been living here for about 10 years now, so I think I have a pretty good handle on the place. When I first moved here from Riverdale to Stockbridge, I gotta admit, I was bummed out. I missed my old neighborhood and everyone in it, but my folks wanted the best for me and my little sister, so we made the switch for better housing, a better school, the whole "not ghetto" deal. 

Over the years, I got used to it. I made some new friends, some not-so-friendly faces too, but hey, that's life, right?  I never really clicked with most of the neighbors, except for Mr. Glen and his kids, and Dennis for a while, since they lived right next door. They're cool people, almost like family, and I'm genuinely grateful to have them. 

I remember when my family went to Mr. Glen's wedding – they got remarried!  It was a blast, a total party, and something I'm looking forward to someday when I'm all settled down with a wife of my own. I even caught the little white strap off his wife, Ms. Veda's leg when she tossed it! Sadly, I missed the bouquet. We danced the night away, and I had a great time hanging with Marsharii, one of their daughters. Haven't seen her since, but I hope she's doing well.

This neighborhood is like a maze, honestly, but now that I have GPS, I'm thinking about exploring it more.  So far, my explorations have mostly been with my buddies Kason and Curtis, back when we were into video games and just living it up. Sometimes I'd chill out at the park, enjoying the peace and quiet. It really calms me down, gives me a sense of serenity. I'll even bring some sticks from Home Depot and practice my balance, sometimes even my bokken wooden sword.  

There's a basketball and tennis court too, although I haven't played in ages. Still, it's nice to have them there just in case I get the urge to pick up a racket or a ball again. My dad got me and my best friend into tennis with Mr. Graves back in the day. We had a blast, and they pushed us hard, but it was always fun. 

Looking back, I've had a lot of good times in this neighborhood. There are tons of stories, but these are the ones that really stick with me.  I have a feeling the best is yet to come!

My neighborhood is pretty sweet because it's right by my college. It's mostly apartments, but there are some decent, affordable bars and restaurants around. One bar just got a fancy makeover and jacked up its prices, but it's not *that* bad. Most people here are either students or just scraping by since the apartments aren't exactly luxurious. There are tons of kids around because of the elementary school a stone's throw away. I don't really know my neighbors, and honestly, I'm good with that. They're pretty heavy into the weed, so the building management put this ridiculous air freshener thing right outside their door. It's hilarious, almost insulting. 

The buildings around here are mostly old-school, but some have been renovated inside. There are some brand-new apartments down the street, but I can't stand them. They're cheaply built and super expensive, a total scam because they're near campus. They get away with it because, well, they're near campus. There's this cheap-ass restaurant a few minutes away that serves everything on paper plates and microwaves most of the food. Across the street is a gas station that supposedly has terrible working conditions. But hey, at least the road was redone last summer with city money. Now there's a nice sidewalk, some greenery, and it actually looks decent. 

My building is surrounded by trees, though they chopped down a few. There's a whole tree line behind the complex, and then another set of apartments. I'm on 42nd street, but behind me is 43rd, which is rougher. The sidewalks are falling apart, the buildings look dingy, and the whole vibe is off. They've got lots of trees there too, probably to hide the buildings. A lot of the crime in the area seems to be concentrated in one apartment complex on 43rd, though I wouldn't blame them entirely. The apartments across the street from me have a pretty high turnover rate and their share of problems too. 

But overall, I'm pretty happy with where I live. It's affordable, convenient, and I'm within walking distance of the university. Plus, there are two bus stops nearby, so getting to the store or downtown is easy peasy.

My neighborhood is a collection of duplexes arranged on a cul-de-sac, spaced out to look like individual houses. They all share the same yellow paint, white porches, and green metal roofs, giving them a uniform look.  Most of the residents know each other well and often gather at the ends of driveways in the evenings. While the kids play, the adults chat and enjoy the simple pleasures of community life. It's a refreshing escape from the constant buzz of technology and feels like stepping back in time.  

We're surrounded by fields, trees, and endless blue skies, but lately, we've been dealing with some stormy weather. This season has brought tornado warnings, and last night, we even heard the sirens. I found myself huddled in my bathtub with my smallest dog, my purse, and a few pillows, while my other dog nervously paced the living room.  The storm unleashed a barrage of hail, and afterward, the ground steamed from the sudden temperature drop. It went from a scorching 92 degrees to a cool 75 in just minutes. The hail melted instantly upon hitting the hot pavement. 

After the storm passed, a double rainbow appeared in the clearing sky. I rushed to grab my camera and snapped some pictures to share with my loved ones. It was a breathtaking sight, and the neighborhood remained quiet for another hour before people started trickling back home. Life returned to normal, with parents and kids outside enjoying the evening air as dinner cooked.  

My new neighborhood in North Carolina is a wonderful place to live. Even though we all have similar two-bedroom, two-bathroom apartments, the interiors vary, with some being surprisingly small.  I love taking walks in the large field behind my apartment and heading down to the pond, where I've seen deer and hear the booming call of a giant bullfrog each morning. It's a peaceful retreat just forty minutes outside of Charlotte.  

Every morning is greeted by the sound of roosters crowing from nearby farms, making it feel like living in a small, close-knit village. Even the local donkey braying in the evening adds to the charm.  I feel incredibly lucky to have found this hidden gem of a neighborhood.

Moving into this neighborhood right before eighth grade was a bit rough at first. Making friends took some time, but I eventually became close with a couple of guys – one lives two houses down and the other on my street. They've since moved, but those memories stick with me.  Most of the folks who were here when I first moved are still around. It's a pretty typical American suburb, full of two-story houses. Weekends, or any time the weather's nice, you can hear kids playing outside. It's pretty quiet most days, though. I've never had any issues with anyone here. You're pretty much left to your own devices unless you need something, which is cool. I've ordered tons of stuff online and never had a package disappear from my porch. I trust my neighbors.

There's a park just a couple minutes from my house, loaded with memories. Played basketball, football, baseball there with the neighborhood crew. Even got a nasty elbow to the nose playing football, but the good times definitely outweigh the bad. Now, when I go, it's mostly to hang with my cousin's kids. They're way younger than me and still into swings and slides and that kinda stuff. Just thinking about the park gets them pumped! It's pretty nostalgic for me now, for a bunch of reasons.

The neighborhood's pretty diverse, with all kinds of food options nearby. Within a mile, you can find Chinese, Indian, Mexican, Italian – the works. Though, these days, a lot of people just use apps like GrubHub and DoorDash for delivery. The usual suspects are the fast food chains, which you can find anywhere in the suburbs, and there are tons of pizza places too.  The stores here have everything you could need. Plenty of dry cleaners, a Walgreens and a CVS on the same street, even a Jewel-Osco grocery store, a Midwest staple. There's even an Indian-owned store if you're in the mood for homemade or ready-made Indian food.

Overall, I dig my neighborhood. Reading about other people's nightmare neighbors on social media and the news makes me appreciate mine even more.

My town, Johnston, isn't exactly a standout in South Carolina. It's just your average, run-of-the-mill town, but it's got this big claim to fame: it's the "Peach Capital of the World." You'll see it plastered on the welcome sign, and it's pretty much true.  The whole place is basically one giant peach orchard or cattle ranch.  

The houses are spread out, mostly two-story affairs with either metal roofs or gray shingles, probably to deal with the scorching summer heat. They're usually tucked back from the road, giving way to fields for animals or crops. The heart of town is pretty small, with just one stoplight at a four-way intersection. That's where you'll find the only stores in town. 

You've got your usual fast food options: Hong Kong, a tiny Chinese spot run by a family, Fiesta Mexican Restaurant, and Gary's, a local burger chain. Sadly, the pizza place closed down recently. There's a little family pharmacy, Maxwell and Halford Drug, known more for their Cherry Coca-Cola than anything else. And then there's IGA, the only grocery store but it's kind of pricey, so most people head to Walmart in the next town over for groceries. The real star of the show is Dollar General – it's always packed with folks grabbing everyday essentials.

There's also Possibilities Furniture & More, a charming little store run by a local legend. They even have movers who'll deliver your furniture! Attached to the furniture store is Clark's Cuts and Kennels, a pet groomer that does it all: daycare, boarding, grooming, the works. 

The doctor's office and the vet are both tucked away from the main drag, but they're well-equipped to take care of the town's needs. There's just one elementary school, Johnston Elementary. After fifth grade, kids have to head to the next town for middle and high school. 

Parks? Well, they're working on a 2.5-acre park, but for now, there aren't really any. No movie theaters, bowling alleys, or places to hang out. It's pretty quiet here. But hey, it's a nice place to live, small enough to be overlooked.

My first encounter with my current neighborhood came through a podcast about missing people, which was a bit of a shock. I mean, rents here are sky-high, often exceeding a thousand dollars a month.  It was surprising to learn about this story, as neither I nor any of my friends had ever heard of it. Maybe it's the struggle of making ends meet that makes these things happen. I know some friends who have tough nights, crying themselves to sleep because of the cost of living. Things are expensive, but we've become masters of frugality over the years. We've learned to appreciate the charm of dusty flea market treasures and moth-eaten clothes. As we age, we tend to smell less, perhaps because we're more used to the way things are. But the flea market always holds its own. The smell of adulthood for me is a mix of dusty magazines piled on a closed piano, lingering in the leather even after washing it. 

Speaking of flea markets, there are three thrift stores within walking distance here. Starting from one end, you can visit two charity shops, a library, a rare book store, and a quirky curio shop. Downtown is bustling with cars and people every morning, but the thrift stores are peaceful sanctuaries. No matter how many people or vehicles pass by, there's a hush inside. It's a perfect place to lose yourself for an afternoon. Every year, the city seems to get denser, with more cars and people. They call it a developing city, a place where one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery is headquartered. It's still growing, showing signs of those growing pains. It reminds me of New York City – everyone's focused on their own goals, and there's not much expectation of anything from anyone else. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will respect your space. It's not like the South, where showing a little concern is seen as genuine care. People here don't pry into your life. You can keep your guard up as long as you like, and the city rolls on, like waves on a beach. It's a lively place to be. 

Between the pianist next door and the two amateur vocalists upstairs, there's always something happening. In a way, we're less like strangers in an apartment building and more like a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and support each other when we can. I feel fortunate to be here. I like most of my neighbors, and they treat me well. I make an effort to keep my space clean and leave them food, and they do the same for me. I bring them their mail, and they bring me mine. It's nice to see them, and I believe they enjoy my company as much as I do theirs. I live in a massive, impersonal modernist sprawl, but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I haven't completely messed up my life.

So, where I live is like, your basic, everyday suburb, y'know?  There's a homeowner's association here that's *really* into keeping things looking neat and tidy.  Driving around, you'll see rows and rows of identical houses, all perfectly manicured lawns, a sprinkle of decorative rocks, and tiny driveways.  Every once in a while, there's a small tree trying to break up the monotony, and two-car garages are the norm. The roads are always freshly paved, which is nice, but kinda boring.  I mean, you won't find any potholes or anything, but it's all just...predictable. Most of the houses are one story, but a few have two. And the mail situation?  Forget those individual mailboxes you see everywhere else – we've got a huge communal box at the end of the street, like an apartment building.  Key required, of course.  Gotta keep things uniform, right?

My place is kind of on the edge of the city, so it's kinda like a mix of rural and suburban.  We've got tons of space, which is cool. There are a bunch of community pools – gated and well-maintained – and walking trails everywhere.  You don't even need to go to a park to get your steps in.  The neighborhood's mostly made up of retired folks, so it's super safe and everyone knows each other.  There are a few younger folks and middle-aged professionals mixed in, but not many.  

The city itself is pretty big, population-wise, but it still feels like a small town.  We've got all the basic stuff you need, like a mall – not huge, but it does the trick. It takes about 15 minutes to get anywhere decent though.  We've got everything from fancy organic grocery stores to bargain outlets with half the staff and twice the dusty shelves. Overall, it's a pretty standard, safe, and well-kept neighborhood.

My town's kinda like that quiet cousin of a bigger city. It's got a small-town feel, but you're close enough to the city stuff if you need it. My part of town, on the east side, isn't the fanciest.  Houses are older, mostly rentals, and you know, sometimes things go missing from porches if you're not careful.  But it's not a bad place. Folks are friendly, wave when you walk by, and crime, while it happens, isn't anything crazy. There have been some rough incidents, shootings a few blocks over, even a homicide. We lost a neighbor’s son to a shooting last year, which was tough. But overall, we're lucky - nothing major has ever directly hit home.

The whole opioid thing has been a big weight on our town, like everywhere else.  We've lost people, but there are a lot of good resources trying to fight it - rehab centers, Narcan training, that kind of thing.

But hey, there are good things here too. My son’s school is amazing, from the teachers to the staff. He’s got special needs, but they make him feel right at home. The school even gives free breakfast and lunch to all the kids because a lot of families struggle.  

The town's been trying to spruce itself up, but most of the work seems to be focused downtown, where the shops and traffic are. Our side gets a little forgotten, which can be frustrating.

Still, we love it here. It’s our home. People are good, the school's great, we've got everything we need, and our house, well, it's comfortable. We've been here for 16 years, and we wouldn't trade it for the world.

My neighborhood is a vibrant mix of history and character. It's nestled on a hill, surrounded by buildings that whisper tales of the past. I live in a seven-story apartment building right across from an old theater, and just down the street, there's this awesome arcade bar that draws in all sorts of folks on warm summer evenings. On weekends, especially in June and July, you'll often see a line snaking out the door. A few blocks up is the local park, surprisingly spacious for this part of town. It's enclosed by concrete with these steep stairs built right into the wall. During the harsh winter months, you'll see homeless people setting up their tents in neat rows along the sidewalk and on those wide steps. Though it doesn't snow much, the heavy downpours in mid-winter can make staying warm a real struggle. By clustering their tents together, they find warmth and are close to the only family center for miles, where they can find a hot shower and a chance to freshen up. What I truly love about my city, though, isn't the beauty of its historical landmarks – the towering buildings, the architecture that climbs the hills rolling down to the ocean.  It's the spirit of the people.  Hilltop used to be notorious for gang violence on the West Coast, and even today, stories from those days, when federal agents and the DEA would swoop in, echo through the neighborhood. The people here remember. These stories are passed down through generations, even to newcomers like me. Despite still being considered a rough area, the residents work hard to keep it clean and safe. They care deeply about their community. There are warnings about not walking around alone at night if you're white, but I think those are echoes of the past, a remnant of old prejudices. Maybe it's because I'm dark enough to pass as something other than a "white girl," or maybe Hilltop sees me as one of their own, someone who understands the constant reminders of racism and social conditioning that plague our nation. Even in a city that prides itself on being a melting pot of cultures. One thing is for sure: no matter where I go, Hilltop will always be home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, encountering people who offer me a jacket more readily than a threat. It's a place where laundromat owners stay open late so I can charge my phone when caught in a downpour. It's a place where I've sat, feeling invisible, huddled against store fronts on the bleakest nights, only to have someone stop, look me in the eye, hand me five dollars, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.

I call home a slice of Rural America, tucked away in a small town in Michigan. You'll find no towering skyscrapers or sprawling shopping centers here – no Walmart, Target, not even an Applebee's in sight. You've gotta hit the road to get anything you need. Despite the lack of big-city amenities, I wouldn't trade this place for the world. It's surrounded by breathtaking water: Lake Michigan on one side, Lake Charlevoix on the other.  Beaches are practically everywhere you turn, perfect for dipping your toes and soaking up the sun.

My neighborhood is straight out of a quintessential small town picture book. Homes aren't crammed together, each one unique, some sporting a modern makeover, others proudly showcasing their age.  Most have full basements, visible from the street, and a kaleidoscope of colors adorns the aluminum siding of many. Yards are plentiful, bursting with life – trampolines bouncing, kids' playsets whirring, gardens flourishing, and fences keeping furry friends safe. It's a community of hard-working folks, raising families or cherishing the memories they've made.

You'll see kids zooming down sidewalks, dogs getting their daily walk, and neighbors cycling or rollerblading. There's a real sense of belonging here, a knowing glance exchanged between those who call this place home and those who are just passing through.  The air hums with the friendly chatter of neighbors grilling outside, a wave here, a smile there. Lawns are manicured with pride, free from fallen leaves and overgrown weeds.  

It's not about flashy homes, but about creating a sense of community, a place where families thrive. The quiet streets, the friendly faces, the feeling of safety – these are the things that make this neighborhood special. It's a place where you can let your guard down, knowing that you're among friends. 

The county sheriff's department and jail are within walking distance, a reassuring presence in the community.  The health department is right next door, and the city recycling center is just down the road, a testament to the town's commitment to sustainability. 

Baseball and softball games echo through the air, the announcer's voice painting vivid pictures of the players' triumphs.  The small town airport, a stone's throw away, adds a little bit of excitement to the day with the rumble of small planes taking off and landing.  A local ice cream parlor is within easy reach, and a short bike ride takes you to the park, where kids can run free.

It might not be a glamorous place, but it's home. It's a place where life moves at a slower pace, where neighbors become friends, and where you can truly feel a sense of belonging.

original_texts:
I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
The general area in which I live in can be described as your typical cookie cutter suburbia. For my neighborhood in particular, the presence of a homeowner's association is very apparent. Upon entering, you'll see nothing but well-maintained single family homes, which we can thank the homeowner's association for. The front yards are all very similar. There's a small patch of landscaped grass, some decorative pebbles, and rather short driveways. Every so often you'll see small trees as well. Everyone has a two car garage. As you continue to drive along throughout the neighborhood you'll see newly paved concrete. Despite many different families living here, the roads are in excellent condition. You won't find any potholes or anything like that here. Most of the houses are single story, but sometimes you'll see two stories as well. We don't have a typical mailbox set-up that you would expect for single family homes. There are no individual mailboxes in front of each house. Instead, it's more like apartments where there are a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street. Everyone uses a key to gain access their specific mailbox. And there's two larger lockers for packages. Again, you can thank the HOA and their obsession with uniformity for this. The location of my house is on the extreme edge of the nearby city, so my neighborhood can be described as part rural, part suburbs. As a result, we have a lot of land for, well, everything. There's multiple community pools to which anyone living here can access. It's well maintained and gated. And then there are various walking trails where you can walk your dog, or just go for an evening stroll by yourself. You don't have to visit a park to get your exercise in. The neighborhood is large enough that you can simply run around it and get more than enough exercise. Most of the community is made up of retired people. It's a very safe area, and everyone looks out for one another. Mixed in with that, we have a small amount of middle aged and young professionals too. In regards to the city, it's surprisingly large - at least by population - but also has a small time town feel. We have the vast majority of amenities that you come to expect and rely on. For example, we have a exactly one mall. It's not huge, but it gets the job done. For me, it takes around 15 minutes of driving to get anywhere significant, but once I do that, I am greeted with many different stores to choose from. We have everything from high end grocery stores where you can get organic food, to bargain outlets that only stock a small selection of items and has bare minimum staff to keep costs down. All in all, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and pretty typical. We have a lot of nice things, like pools and walking trails. And although we aren't right next door to any sort of shopping, you can just hop in a car and go to any major chain that you'd like.
The first time I'd heard of my place, I was listening to a podcast about people who'd gone missing. It was a little surprising. Almost every apartment in the area was going for over a thousand dollars a month. I'd never heard anything about that story and neither had any of my friends. Maybe it's the struggle. I know a few of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Things are expensive, but we've learned how to be frugal over the years. You start to like the dusty smell of flea market toys and mothballed clothes. You smell a lot less in adulthood. You might start to smoke, or you might just be too accustomed to the state of things. But the flea market always asserts itself. The smell of adulthood is dusty magazines stacked on a closed piano. It wedges itself in the leather and stays in even after you wash it. Here, there're 3 thrift stores in walking distance. If you start on the far side, you can patronize two charity thrifts, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is dense, cars and people fill the streets every morning, but you'd never hear it in the thrifts. No matter how many people or cars pass by, the store is silent. It's a nice place to lose an afternoon. Every year, there's more and more of those. Cars and people flood it. It's a developing city, they say. Headquartering one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery, it's still showing growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everything and everyone is set on their own goals, and there isn't a whole lot anyone asks from you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will leave you alone. It's not like the South, where being a little concerned means you care. You don't pry into anyone's life here, really. You can keep up your shell as long as you'd like, and the city will crash and roll back like waves on the beach. It's a lively place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur vocalists upstairs, there's always something going on. In a way, we have less of an apartment of strangers and more a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and help each other when we can. In a way, I'm lucky to be here. I quite like most of my neighbors and they treat me pretty well. I try to make sure to clean after myself and leave them food and they do the same in kind. I bring mail to them and they to me. It's nice to see them and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I do theirs. I live in a massive, dehumanizing modernist sprawl but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I didn't totally ruin my life.
I live in a small Midwestern town that is just outside the suburban areas of a major city. My immediate neighborhood, on the east side of the town, could be described as the most economically disadvantaged area of the town. Property values are low, with most houses being rented to or owned by low-income individuals. However, it is not unattractive or unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who will smile and say hello when I walk down the street. Crime rates, while slightly higher than other parts of town, are still generally low. There have been a few violent crimes in the past ten years within a few blocks of my home, including a few shootings and at least one homicide. Our next door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside an area bar last year. Fortunately, our family has not been directly affected by crime other than having an occasional item disappear from our porch if we forget to bring it inside. In general, the town in which I live has been profoundly affected by the “opioid epidemic” that has affected many parts of the United States. Many lives have been lost due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are many resources in my town to combat this epidemic, including several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, this town has many positive attributes. My son’s elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff. Despite having special needs, he has not faced any bullying thus far due to the incredibly positive atmosphere of the school, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that plans multiple events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. Because over 20% of our town’s population lives below the poverty level, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, so that no child ever has to go hungry. No child or family is treated as “less than” due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made many improvements to the appearance of our town, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most of these improvements have taken place in the center of town and on the west side, where all of the shopping areas are located and most of the traffic passes through. The east side where I live tends to be neglected, which is a point of contention for those in my neighborhood. Overall, I do enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, the schools are great, there are enough shopping options (both small businesses and larger retail stores) to meet my family’s needs, and our home may not be worth much, but it is comfortable and adequate. Our family has lived here for over 16 years, and we cannot imagine living anywhere else.
My neighborhood is full of culture. It's set upon a hill, surrounded by buildings with historical meaning. I live in a 7 story apartment building right across from the old live Theater, and a block down The Hill, is this cool little arcade bar that different types of people flock to on warm summer nights. Often times, especially on the weekends in June and July, you will see a line of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park. It's pretty big considering the part of town it sits in. Encircling the park is concrete, with tall stairs poured into the wall. During the frigid winter months, homeless people set their tents up in neat little rows along the sidewalk and along the wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains, and the torrential down pour in the mid-winter months often tends to make it difficult to keep warm. Setting their tents up close together, in the center of town rather than out in the jungle, keeps them much warmer. They're also within reasonable walking and transit distance to the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city though, isn't the beauty of the historic nature- the tall proud buildings, the architecture that is spattered through-out the varying levels of the hills that roll down towards the ocean. What I love about my neighborhood is the culture of the people themselves. You see, Hilltop once was the most notorious neighborhood on the West Coast for gang violence. You still hear stories, even three decades later, about the federal government officials and the DEA sweeping through like a broom, trying to clean the streets. The people, they don't forget. Stories are still passed from generation to generation, on through to transplants like me, of those days. The people work hard, even though it's still considered one of the rougher 'hoods' in the entire city, to keep it cleaned up. They still care about what goes on in their city, on their block. They say that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around the Hill after dark. Truly, I believe that this warning is reminiscent of the old days, and it is tinged with the sour taste of social conditioning. Perhaps it is that I am just dark enough to pass for a not entirely "white-girl," or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, someone who is just as painfully aware of the reminders that constantly plague our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions are made out of ignorance and fear, even in a city that is supposed to be a cultural melting pot Utopia. I know one thing: no matter how far I roam, the Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who have more quickly and rarely nefariously offered me a jacket than to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open just a few minutes later so I could charge my phone when I had no where to escape from the rain. It's a place where I have sat, believe myself to be invisible, huddled against concrete store fronts on the most grey dreary of nights, only to have someone stop and look me in the eye, hand me a $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.
I moved to this neighborhood just when I was about to start eighth grade. It was hard for me to make friends at first, but I ended up getting close to someone who lives two houses down from me and another guy that lives on my street. Neither of them lives there anymore but the memories are still there. The same people who lived here when I first moved here are still here for the most part. My neighborhood is pretty similar to your average American suburban neighborhood. The neighborhood has a lot of two-story houses in it. Every weekend or just whenever it is warm outside I hear the kids playing outside. The neighborhood is quiet most days of the week. I have never had a problem with any of the people in the neighborhood. You are left alone in this neighborhood unless you need help. I have ordered multiple packages online and have never gotten a package snatched off of my porch. I feel like I can trust my neighbors. There is a park a minute or two away from my house. I have a lot of memories there. I have played basketball, football, and baseball there with the other guys in the neighborhood before. I also ended up with one of my worst memories there when I got elbowed in the nose playing football, but the good memories outweigh the bad. Nowadays, whenever I go to that park it is to spend time with my cousin's kids. They are much younger than me and still like playing on swings and slides and all of that type of stuff. Just the thought of going to the park makes them excited. The park makes me very nostalgic for a number of different reasons now. The neighborhood is very diverse. You will find all kinds of food nearby. In just a one mile radius, you would be able to find Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants. However, nowadays, a lot of people just use apps just as GrubHub and DoorDash to get their food delivered to them. The most popular food places are the fast food shops but you can get those near pretty much any suburban neighborhood. There are also plenty of pizza places. The stores here contain everything you would ever need. There are multiple dry cleaners nearby. There is a Walgreens and a CVS on the same street as well as a Jewel-Osco grocery store, which is popular in the Midwest. Some of the stores are even diverse as there is an Indian-owned store if you are ever in the mood to make some homemade Indian food or to buy some ready-made Indian food. Overall, I am a fan of my neighborhood. Reading on social media and seeing on the news some of the horror stories other people have to go through with their neighbors makes me grateful for mine.
My neighborhood is nearby to the college that I attend, and for that I quite enjoy living there. There are mostly apartment buildings, but a few restaurants and bars that are fun to go to and aren't terribly expensive to go to. One of the bars was just renamed, and that one is more expensive to go to but it isn't really the worst quality of service or drinks there. Most of the people are nice. They are either college kids or they are lower income, since the apartment housing isn't very expensive. There's a lot of children nearby since there is an elementary school within walking distance of my apartment. I don’t know my neighbors, but I don’t really want to. They smoke a lot of weed and so the management of my building put an air freshener unit right across from their door, which my boyfriend and I found very funny. It’s almost insulting. The buildings that are around me are usually pretty old looking but might have renovated interiors. Down the street a bit there are brand new apartments, but I don’t like them because I know the construction done on them wasn’t particularly good. They’re cheaply built but the rent is expensive, which I think is such a scam but because they’re near campus, the management of those buildings can get away with it. There is a really cheap restaurant about five minutes from where I live that serves food only on paper plates and most of what they make is microwaved. Then across from that is a gas station, which I’ve heard isn’t a very good place to work. But thanks to some money from the city, the road was redone last summer so that there’s a nice big sidewalk, lots of grass on the medians and sides of the roads, and now the area is a little nicer. But the apartment building I live in is shrouded in tress. They cut a few of them down, so there are a few stumps, but there are a lot more trees where I live than down the road. Behind my apartment complex is a tree line and then another set of apartments. I live on 42nd street, but right behind is 43rd street and that one isn’t as nice. The sidewalks are really bad and falling apart, and most of the buildings on it look shabby. There are a lot of trees on this street, but that is probably to hide what the buildings look like. Most of the crime in my area has happened at an apartment complex on that street, but then again, I can’t blame just them. There are apartments across the street from me that also have a lot of crime and a rather transient population. But I think I like where I live. I can afford it, and there’s plenty of useful amenities nearby. I especially like how the university is within walking distance and there are two bus stops so that I can get to the store and downtown with ease.
My neighborhood is made up of duplex's on a cul-de-sac. They are intermittently placed and spaced so that they look like individual houses. The only difference is each is painted yellow with white porches and green metal roofs. Almost everyone, but not all, are friends with each other. We stand at the end of a not pre-decided driveway some evenings and chit chat while the small children of the neighborhood play with their toys, sidewalk chalk or fly their kites. It is very refreshing in this modern all to mechanical/computer filled world. It is rather like stepping back in time. We are surrounded by fields and trees enhanced by blue skies and white billowing clouds. The only downfall? This season, we are experiencing tornado warnings and for the first time, last night we actually heard actual tornado sirens so we had to head towards shelter. Sure enough, you would have found me in my bathtub clutching my littlest dog along with my purse and a few pillows. My big dog wanted nothing to do with the bathroom and remained in the livingroom, nervous and barking, nervous about the odd circumstances. The neighborhood was quiet except for the sound of large hail which fell all bout the ground. After the storm the road literally was steaming from the change of temperature. We went from 92 to 75 in a matter of minutes. The hail immediately melted when it hit the hot pavement. As I looked up towards the clearing skies, the sun came out and it started to rain. A double rainbow apparated. I ran into the house and grabbed my camera. Quickly snapped pictures to share with my Facebook friends and family. They were in awe, as was I. The streets remained quiet for another hour, before some people finally came home from wherever they were when the thunderstorm hit. Then it was business as usual, mom’s and children outside as dinner cooked. Such a friendly neighborhood for this gal who has recently moved form NH to NC. I adore the southern accent that people speak with. I have a two bedroom and two bath apartment, as does everyone. Though all the houses look the same on the outside, not all of the apartments are the same on the inside. Some are actually quite tiny. It doesn’t make sense to me. I love to walk along the biggest field behind where I live and mosey down to the pond that is not made for swimming. I have seen deer and in the morning you can hear the giant bullfrog singing his song. It is a fantastic place to live just forty minutes outside the city of Charlotte. Each morning is welcomed by the sound of roosters crowing from the surrounding farms. It is rather like living in a small community village of it’s own. We even have a donkey at a nearby farm that you can hear braying in the evening to let us know he is there. I was lucky to find this gem of a neighborhood.
Well, considering that I’ve been here for about 10 years, I guess I can share what I know. First off, I was pretty sad when I first came to my neighborhood. I came from Riverdale to Stockbridge, and I’m not going to lie, I cried, because I missed them and I loved them.. but my mom and dad wanted the best for me and my little sister, so we moved to a better location for housing, a better high school, everything was considered “not ghetto” when we moved to our new neighborhood. Throughout the years, I got used to it, and made some new friends, and some new enemies too in school. I never really truly got to know my neighbors throughout the years, except Mr. Glen and his children, as well as Dennis for a bit, both being right next to us. They have been enjoyable people that I almost can consider as family in some ways, and I truly do appreciate them. I remember when me, mom, dad, and my sister went to Mr. Glen’s wedding (They got re-married) It was really fun and enjoyable to say the least, and something I’m looking forward to someday, as I build my wealth and give my future wife the life of a Queen. When Mr. Glen’s wife, Ms. Veda, took off the white little strap on her leg and threw it, I caught it! Sadly I didn’t catch the flowers! We all danced the night away, and I really enjoyed having a good time with Marsharii, one of their daughters. I haven’t seen her since though. I hope she’s moved on to bigger and better things. The neighborhood itself is like a maze, although now I have a GPS, so I can take more time to explore it. I’ve only went so far, and that is when I’ve hung out with my friends Kason and Curtis. We all used to play video games alot, and just enjoy life to the fullest as much as we could. Sometimes I would go to the park and enjoy nature, which soothes my soul. It gives me a sense of calmness and peace these days. I’ll also bring some sticks that I bought from home depot and just practice my balance, And bring my bokken wooden sword if I can,. I have fun enjoying what I love to do. There’s also a basketball and tennis court, although I haven’t played tennis or basketball in a long time, It’s still nice to have in case I ever want to pick it back up and give it another go. My dad grew me and my best friend up on Tennis with Mr. Graves, and we’d always have a great time.. They worked us hard! But we always had fun. I guess there’s a lot of times I’ve had fun in this neighborhood, and there’s plenty of stories, but these are what really stuck out to me, and I believe that the best, is yet to come!
My neighborhood is a quaint little town. It doesn't stand out from any other in South Carolina, but it's got a significant impact on the agriculture sector. Johnston is known as the Peach Capital of the World, something that the town proudly boasts about on the welcoming sign. It's primarily composed of farmland dominated by either peach trees or cattle. Houses that aren't located within the main part of town are widely spaced apart; most are two stories with either metal roofs to help combat the blazing summer heat or gray shingles. More often than not these houses aren't located near the road, but are further back allowing for the front fields to be used for animals/crops. Within the main part of town, there's a single stop light that hangs at a four way. Here is where the only stores in the entire town are located. There are three places in which you can get "fast food': Hong Kong, a small Chinese restaurant run by a single family, Fiesta Mexican Restaurant, or Gary's, a small burger chain. There used to be a pizzeria, however it closed down a short time ago. There is a very small family-owned pharmacy called Maxwell and Halford Drug; funnily enough, they're best known for the Cherry Coca-Cola they sell. There is a small, but expensive grocery store called Independent Grocers Alliance, more commonly known as IGA. While it is the only grocery store in the entire town, many individuals only stop to pick up one or two items; most prefer to travel to a Walmart in Batesburg-Leesville in order to purchase the majority of their groceries. The most popular store in the entire town is Dollar General; this store sells a vast array of everyday items and it often busy from the moment it opens until closing time! There is a very small furniture store, Possibilities Furniture & More, run by a kind woman who is well-known within the community. The store has been in Johnston for a plethora of years and even employs two movers who will deliver the purchased furniture! Attached to the furniture store building is a small pet groomers called Clark's Cuts and Kennels. They provide a multitude of services such as daycare, boarding, grooming, nail grinding, bathing, etc. Both a doctor's and veterinary practice are situated away from the primary part of town; they are both very small practices, though well-equipped to aid the residents of Johnston. There is a single elementary school called Johnston Elementary School. Once students have completed fifth grade, they must attend both middle and high school in the next town over. There are technically no parks within the town, however they are currently in the midst of creating a 2.5 acre recreational area in order to provide families with more opportunities to enjoy outings and attract more visitors/potential residents. Admittedly there isn't much to do; there are no movie theaters, bowling alleys, "hang out" spots, playgrounds for children, areas to walk pets, or a large variety of restaurants. Despite this it's a nice town, so small that you could pass in the blink of an eye without realizing!
I live in a typical suburb area in a small southern town in Tennessee. It's a connecting street between two state highways, so we get a bit more traffic on the street than I'd like, but other than that, it's a quiet neighborhood. There's not too many folks that move in and out, so I've grown used to most of the people that live in the neighborhood. People busy themselves with yard work and other daily chores for the most part. In the winter, we sled down a hill on our side street. We live in a house at the front corner of our street, so we see everyone coming and going all day long and are familiar with the cars that people drive around here. Whenever we see a strange vehicle, we tend to take note of it. Some of the neighbors go walking for exercise or just to walk their dogs. Kids play on their bikes and all that you would expect from that. We are at home a lot since we work from our house.
